segment.source: Sysprep (Generalize) a Windows installation
segment.target: Sysprep (Generalize) a Windows installation

segment.source: Sysprep (Generalize) a Windows installation
segment.target: Sysprep (Generalize) a Windows installation

segment.source: Sysprep (Generalize) a Windows installation
segment.target: Sysprep (Generalize) a Windows installation

segment.source: Use Sysprep to generalize a Windows installation.
segment.target: Use Sysprep to generalize a Windows installation.

segment.source: To deploy a Windows image to different PCs, you must first prepare the image.
segment.target: To deploy a Windows image to different PCs, you must first prepare the image.

segment.source: You can either use the System Preparation (Sysprep) tool or you can specify a setting in an answer file to prepare the image as part of an unattended installation.
segment.target: You can either use the System Preparation (Sysprep) tool or you can specify a setting in an answer file to prepare the image as part of an unattended installation.

segment.source: To prepare the image, you must remove the computer-specific information from the image.
segment.target: To prepare the image, you must remove the computer-specific information from the image.

segment.source: This process is called generalizing the image.
segment.target: This process is called generalizing the image.

segment.source: In most deployment scenarios, you no longer have to use the answer file setting to reset the Windows Product Activation clock when you run the Sysprep command multiple times on a computer.
segment.target: In most deployment scenarios, you no longer have to use the answer file setting to reset the Windows Product Activation clock when you run the Sysprep command multiple times on a computer.

segment.source: The setting is used to specify the Windows licensing state.
segment.target: The setting is used to specify the Windows licensing state.

segment.source: If you specify a retail product key or volume license product key, Windows is automatically activated.
segment.target: If you specify a retail product key or volume license product key, Windows is automatically activated.

segment.source: You can run the Sysprep command up to 8 additional times on a single Windows image.
segment.target: You can run the Sysprep command up to 8 additional times on a single Windows image.

segment.source: After running Sysprep 8 times, you must recreate your Windows image.
segment.target: After running Sysprep 8 times, you must recreate your Windows image.

segment.source: For more information about Windows components and settings that you can add to an answer file, see the Unattended Windows Setup Reference.
segment.target: For more information about Windows components and settings that you can add to an answer file, see the Unattended Windows Setup Reference.

segment.source: Caution
segment.target: Caution

segment.source: Don't use the Windows Store to update your Windows Store apps before running sysprep /generalize.
segment.target: Don't use the Windows Store to update your Windows Store apps before running sysprep /generalize.

segment.source: Sysprep fails to generalize the image in this scenario.
segment.target: Sysprep fails to generalize the image in this scenario.

segment.source: This issue also applies to the Windows Store apps (for example, Mail, Maps, Bing Finance, Bing News, and others).
segment.target: This issue also applies to the Windows Store apps (for example, Mail, Maps, Bing Finance, Bing News, and others).

segment.source: This can occur when you are customizing your installation in audit mode as the built in administrator, or when using a specific user account.
segment.target: This can occur when you are customizing your installation in audit mode as the built in administrator, or when using a specific user account.

segment.source: The following error appears in the sysprep log files (%WINDIR%System32SysprepPanther):
segment.target: The following error appears in the sysprep log files (%WINDIR%System32SysprepPanther):

segment.source: Sysprep /generalize requires that all apps are provisioned for all users.
segment.target: Sysprep /generalize requires that all apps are provisioned for all users.

segment.source: However, when you update an app from the Windows Store, that app becomes non-provisioned and is tied that user account.
segment.target: However, when you update an app from the Windows Store, that app becomes non-provisioned and is tied that user account.

segment.source: Instead of using the Windows Store to update your apps, you should sideload updates to your line-of-business apps, or have end-users update their apps by using the Windows Store on their destination PCs.
segment.target: Instead of using the Windows Store to update your apps, you should sideload updates to your line-of-business apps, or have end-users update their apps by using the Windows Store on their destination PCs.

segment.source: In managed environments, if Windows Store access is disabled by an IT administrator, you will not be able to update the Windows Store apps.
segment.target: In managed environments, if Windows Store access is disabled by an IT administrator, you will not be able to update the Windows Store apps.

segment.source: For more information about sideloading line-of-business Windows Store apps, see Sideload Apps with DISM and Customize the Start Screen.
segment.target: For more information about sideloading line-of-business Windows Store apps, see Sideload Apps with DISM and Customize the Start Screen.

segment.source: If your server has Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service (RADIUS) clients or remote RADIUS server groups defined in the Network Policy Server (NPS) configuration, you should remove this information before you deploy it to a different computer.
segment.target: If your server has Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service (RADIUS) clients or remote RADIUS server groups defined in the Network Policy Server (NPS) configuration, you should remove this information before you deploy it to a different computer.

segment.source: For more information, see Prepare a Network Policy Server (NPS) for Imaging.
segment.target: For more information, see Prepare a Network Policy Server (NPS) for Imaging.

segment.source: In this topic:
segment.target: In this topic:

segment.source: Generalizing an Image
segment.target: Generalizing an Image

segment.source: Generalizing a Virtual Hard Disk
segment.target: Generalizing a Virtual Hard Disk

segment.source: Generalizing an Image
segment.target: Generalizing an Image

segment.source: When you generalize a Windows image, Windows Setup processes settings in the generalize configuration pass.
segment.target: When you generalize a Windows image, Windows Setup processes settings in the generalize configuration pass.

segment.source: You must run the Sysprep command together with the /generalize option, even if the technician computer and the reference computer have the same hardware configuration.
segment.target: You must run the Sysprep command together with the /generalize option, even if the technician computer and the reference computer have the same hardware configuration.

segment.source: The Sysprep /generalize command removes unique information from a Windows installation so that you can safely reuse that image on a different computer.
segment.target: The Sysprep /generalize command removes unique information from a Windows installation so that you can safely reuse that image on a different computer.

segment.source: But, you can persist drivers during the generalize configuration pass.
segment.target: But, you can persist drivers during the generalize configuration pass.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: When you set up your reference computer, Windows Setup installs drivers for any detected devices.
segment.target: When you set up your reference computer, Windows Setup installs drivers for any detected devices.

segment.source: By default, Windows Setup removes these drivers when you generalize the system.
segment.target: By default, Windows Setup removes these drivers when you generalize the system.

segment.source: If you're deploying the image to computers that have the same hardware and devices, you'll want Windows Setup to reinstall these same drivers.
segment.target: If you're deploying the image to computers that have the same hardware and devices, you'll want Windows Setup to reinstall these same drivers.

segment.source: To keep these drivers on the computer during system generalization, set the Microsoft-Windows-PnPSysprep | setting to true.
segment.target: To keep these drivers on the computer during system generalization, set the Microsoft-Windows-PnPSysprep | setting to true.

segment.source: For more information about Sysprep-related Windows components that you can add to an answer file, see the Unattended Windows Setup Reference.
segment.target: For more information about Sysprep-related Windows components that you can add to an answer file, see the Unattended Windows Setup Reference.

segment.source: Windows replaces only the computer security identifier (SID) on the operating system volume when you run Sysprep.
segment.target: Windows replaces only the computer security identifier (SID) on the operating system volume when you run Sysprep.

segment.source: When Sysprep generalizes an image, it generalizes only the general partition.
segment.target: When Sysprep generalizes an image, it generalizes only the general partition.

segment.source: So if a single computer has multiple operating systems, you must run Sysprep on each image individually.
segment.target: So if a single computer has multiple operating systems, you must run Sysprep on each image individually.

segment.source: To generalize your image
segment.target: To generalize your image

segment.source: Add one of these settings to your answer file:
segment.target: Add one of these settings to your answer file:

segment.source: Use the Microsoft-Windows-Deployment | setting.
segment.target: Use the Microsoft-Windows-Deployment | setting.

segment.source: Set to OOBE or Audit, and set to true.
segment.target: Set to OOBE or Audit, and set to true.

segment.source: The computer automatically generalizes the image and shuts down.
segment.target: The computer automatically generalizes the image and shuts down.

segment.source: -or-
segment.target: -or-

segment.source: Add the Microsoft-Windows-Deployment | setting to the oobeSystem configuration pass.
segment.target: Add the Microsoft-Windows-Deployment | setting to the oobeSystem configuration pass.

segment.source: Set to Audit.
segment.target: Set to Audit.

segment.source: After the computer boots in audit mode and displays the System Preparation Tool window, use one of these methods:
segment.target: After the computer boots in audit mode and displays the System Preparation Tool window, use one of these methods:

segment.source: In the System Preparation Tool window, click Generalize, click Shutdown, and then click OK.
segment.target: In the System Preparation Tool window, click Generalize, click Shutdown, and then click OK.

segment.source: The computer generalizes the image and shuts down.
segment.target: The computer generalizes the image and shuts down.

segment.source: -or-
segment.target: -or-

segment.source: Close the System Preparation Tool window, open a Command Prompt window as an administrator, and then move to the %WINDIR%system32sysprep directory.
segment.target: Close the System Preparation Tool window, open a Command Prompt window as an administrator, and then move to the %WINDIR%system32sysprep directory.

segment.source: Use the Sysprep command together with the /generalize, /shutdown, and /oobe options.
segment.target: Use the Sysprep command together with the /generalize, /shutdown, and /oobe options.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: The computer generalizes the image and shuts down.
segment.target: The computer generalizes the image and shuts down.

segment.source: After the computer shuts down, use an image-capturing tool to capture your image.
segment.target: After the computer shuts down, use an image-capturing tool to capture your image.

segment.source: You can use the Dism /capture-image command in the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool for this purpose.
segment.target: You can use the Dism /capture-image command in the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool for this purpose.

segment.source: Deploy this image to a reference computer.
segment.target: Deploy this image to a reference computer.

segment.source: When the reference computer boots, it displays the Out-Of-Box Experience (OOBE) screen.
segment.target: When the reference computer boots, it displays the Out-Of-Box Experience (OOBE) screen.

segment.source: For more information, see Settings for Automating OOBE andConfigure Oobe.xml.
segment.target: For more information, see Settings for Automating OOBE andConfigure Oobe.xml.

segment.source: If you have additional customizations, you can enter audit mode manually and make those customizations before you generalize and deploy your image.
segment.target: If you have additional customizations, you can enter audit mode manually and make those customizations before you generalize and deploy your image.

segment.source: Optional: To enter audit mode manually before you generalize your image
segment.target: Optional: To enter audit mode manually before you generalize your image

segment.source: At the OOBE screen, press Ctrl+Shift+F3.
segment.target: At the OOBE screen, press Ctrl+Shift+F3.

segment.source: Windows reboots the computer in audit mode, and the System Preparation Tool window appears.
segment.target: Windows reboots the computer in audit mode, and the System Preparation Tool window appears.

segment.source: Caution
segment.target: Caution

segment.source: The Ctrl+Shift+F3 keyboard shortcut doesn't bypass all parts of the OOBE process, such as running scripts and applying answer-file settings in the oobeSystem configuration pass.
segment.target: The Ctrl+Shift+F3 keyboard shortcut doesn't bypass all parts of the OOBE process, such as running scripts and applying answer-file settings in the oobeSystem configuration pass.

segment.source: Add the customizations that you want to include.
segment.target: Add the customizations that you want to include.

segment.source: In the System Preparation Tool window, click Generalize, click Shutdown, and then click OK.
segment.target: In the System Preparation Tool window, click Generalize, click Shutdown, and then click OK.

segment.source: The computer generalizes the image and shuts down.
segment.target: The computer generalizes the image and shuts down.

segment.source: -or-
segment.target: -or-

segment.source: Close the System Preparation Tool window, open a Command Prompt window as an administrator, and then move to the %WINDIR%system32sysprep directory.
segment.target: Close the System Preparation Tool window, open a Command Prompt window as an administrator, and then move to the %WINDIR%system32sysprep directory.

segment.source: Use the Sysprep command together with the /generalize, /shutdown, and /oobe options.
segment.target: Use the Sysprep command together with the /generalize, /shutdown, and /oobe options.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: The computer generalizes the image and shuts down.
segment.target: The computer generalizes the image and shuts down.

segment.source: After the computer shuts down, use an image-capturing tool to capture your image.
segment.target: After the computer shuts down, use an image-capturing tool to capture your image.

segment.source: You can use the Dism /capture-image command in the DISM tool for this purpose.
segment.target: You can use the Dism /capture-image command in the DISM tool for this purpose.

segment.source: Deploy this image to a reference computer.
segment.target: Deploy this image to a reference computer.

segment.source: When the reference computer boots, it displays the OOBE screen.
segment.target: When the reference computer boots, it displays the OOBE screen.

segment.source: For more information about audit mode, see:
segment.target: For more information about audit mode, see:

segment.source: Audit Mode Overview
segment.target: Audit Mode Overview

segment.source: Boot Windows to Audit Mode or OOBE
segment.target: Boot Windows to Audit Mode or OOBE

segment.source: Add a Driver Online in Audit Mode
segment.target: Add a Driver Online in Audit Mode

segment.source: Enable and Disable the Built-in Administrator Account
segment.target: Enable and Disable the Built-in Administrator Account

segment.source: Generalizing a Virtual Hard Disk
segment.target: Generalizing a Virtual Hard Disk

segment.source: You can use Sysprep VM mode to generalize a VHD that you want to deploy as a VHD on the same virtual machine or hypervisor.
segment.target: You can use Sysprep VM mode to generalize a VHD that you want to deploy as a VHD on the same virtual machine or hypervisor.

segment.source: VM mode supports rapid deployment of virtual machines.
segment.target: VM mode supports rapid deployment of virtual machines.

segment.source: VM mode is supported only when you run it from inside a virtual machine.
segment.target: VM mode is supported only when you run it from inside a virtual machine.

segment.source: Additionally, VM mode is available only through the command line.
segment.target: Additionally, VM mode is available only through the command line.

segment.source: You can't use VM mode to prepare a VHD for deployment to any computer.
segment.target: You can't use VM mode to prepare a VHD for deployment to any computer.

segment.source: To generalize a VHD
segment.target: To generalize a VHD

segment.source: In audit mode, open a Command Prompt window as an administrator, and then move to the %WINDIR%system32sysprep directory.
segment.target: In audit mode, open a Command Prompt window as an administrator, and then move to the %WINDIR%system32sysprep directory.

segment.source: Use the Sysprep command together with the /generalize, /oobe, and /mode:vm options.
segment.target: Use the Sysprep command together with the /generalize, /oobe, and /mode:vm options.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: The computer generalizes the VHD image.
segment.target: The computer generalizes the VHD image.

segment.source: Deploy the generalized VHD image on the same virtual machine.
segment.target: Deploy the generalized VHD image on the same virtual machine.

segment.source: When the virtual machine reboots, it displays the OOBE screen.
segment.target: When the virtual machine reboots, it displays the OOBE screen.

segment.source: The only additional options that apply to VM mode are /reboot, /shutdown, and /quit.
segment.target: The only additional options that apply to VM mode are /reboot, /shutdown, and /quit.
